document.masterDocTitle: Redescription of ' Polyzonium ' malagassum, a new synonym of Rhinotus purpureus (Pocock, 1894), with notes about the occurrence of the order Polyzoniida on Madagascar (Diplopoda)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Redescription of ' Polyzonium ' malagassum, a new synonym of Rhinotus purpureus (Pocock, 1894), with notes about the occurrence of the order Polyzoniida on Madagascar (Diplopoda)

bibRefCitation.author: Saussure, H. de & Zehntner, L.
bibRefCitation.journalOrPublisher: Histoire Physique, Naturelle et Politique de Madagascar
bibRefCitation.refString: Saussure, H. de & Zehntner, L. (1902) Myriapodes de Madagascar, In: Grandidier (Ed.), Histoire Physique, Naturelle et Politique de Madagascar, 27 (53), pp. i-viii + 1 - 356, pls. 13 - 15.
bibRefCitation.title: Myriapodes de Madagascar

treatmentCitationGroup.paragraph:
Polyzonium malagassum
de
Saussure & Zehntner, 1902 : 285
(first description)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Material examined. Type material:
1 M lectotype (designated herewith)
,
5 F paratypes (two missing the head),
MNHN B019
. Label data: Madagascar , Grandidier. No precise locality given. Label data fits the data mentioned in the first description 100 %.

paragraph.materialsCitation:
3 F
, MHNG , ' Madagascar' ,
Polyzonium malagassum
, H. de Saussure det. 1903 , newer label inside stating "after Hoffman
Rhinotus
? africanus (Cook)" [another synonym of
R. purpureus
].

subSubSection.paragraph: Redescription. The specimens are in very good condition, ca. 7 mm long with the male lectotype slightly smaller. The width is 0.78 mm in the largest female. The specimens have 38 ( lectotype , 2 F paratypes ) body rings plus telson.

The colour is a faded dark brown with lighter antennae (
Fig. 1
A).

On each side of head with single, large black ocellus (
Fig. 1
B). Collum overlapping head up to lower half of ocellus.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1.
Polyzonium malagassum
de Saussure & Zehntner, 1902 , Multi-layer photographs, lectotype (MNHN B019). A : Habitus; B : Head with ocellus. Abbreviations : Co = collum (tergite 1); Go = gonopods; O = ocellus. Not to scale.

FIGURE 2. Gonopods of the lectotype (MNHN B019), caudal view. A : anterior gonopod; B: posterior gonopod. Abbreviations : Cx = fused coxae; s-c = apical end canal for the posterior gonopods; St = sternite. Scale bars = 0.1 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Gonopods : Anterior gonopod sternite with two rounded lobes, each carrying a long seta (
Fig. 2
A). Coxae fused and massive, with sutures still visible. Each coxa with a long trichostele, carrying a long seta. First podomere small but wide, second podomere massive, third podomere carrying mesally a protruding channel for the tarsus of the posterior gonopod (
Fig. 2
A), as well as a partly covered process further laterally. Podomere 3 laterally with ca. 4 short setae.

Posterior gonopod sternite elongated into two widely separated, rectangular lobes, each carrying 4 or 5 strong setae (
Fig. 2
B). Above the syncoxite with three basal, partly fused and difficult to distinguish podomeres, apically with a very long, slender tarsus. Tarsus apically with a short claw (
Fig. 2
B).

P. malagassum
, a new synonym of
R. purpureus
.
As noted by
Shelley ( 1998 )
,
R. purpureus
is a widespread tramp species introduced to various pacific islands, West Africa, SE Asia, Middle America , the southern USA , several Seychelles islands as well as Madagascar . Individuals of
R. purpureus
were often described as new species, leading to more than a dozen species synonyms (
Hoffman 1980
), and generic synonyms such as
Boninozonium Takakuwa, 1942
;
Orsilochus Attems, 1900
;
Paraburenia Verhoeff, 1939
; and Paraconus Chamberlin, 1945 . In fact, the Malagasy
R. purpureus
was already described as
Orsilochus acuticonus
more than a century ago (
Attems 1910
), and recently synonymized (
Golovatch & Korsos 1992
). Our illustrations of the gonopods of the lectotype of
Polyzonium malagassum
are virtually identical with those illustrated by previous authors (
MauriÃ¨s 1980
,
Golovatch & Korsos 1992
) and clearly show that
P. malagassum
represents another synonym of
R. purpureus
.

Other localities of
R. purpureus
on Madagascar
.
